ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A very interesting class on the media of Africa with a bit of historical background.
I learned about a variety of academic fields that all related to media and power in Africa. I loved looking at similar topics from such a diverse group of perspectives and approaches.

In this course, I learned about how colonialism manifested itself through various forms of media in modern Africa as both a tool of control and an instrument of liberation. We studied units of text (newspapers), sound & screen (radio, cinema, film, video and piracy), and digital networks (social media, mobile phones, music), while also having writing workshops throughout the semester.

Really enjoyed learning about a variety of different media in conversation with one another. I gained an overview history of media across Africa, touching on a number of fascinating moments in a breadth of different contexts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The main strength of the course is professor Keaney! He was very understandable and facilitated online learning in the best way. The structure of the assignments is very similar to English 114, but I think there is more freedom in choosing what you want to write about. All readings were very interesting and most of them were pretty easy to understand even without prior background in the history of Africa.
Professor Keaney fostered an incredibly welcoming and open learning group environment. He was supportive and incredibly helpful and kind.

Strengths: Professor Keaney was fantastic - I have never had a professor who leaves as much feedback on papers as he does (I had at least one comment per line of every essay I submitted), and its so clear that he wants his students to succeed. He always made class enjoyable, and was very receptive to changing the syllabus around or modifying it whenever we felt overwhelmed.

I would be interested to learn about a few other media - e.g. music, television, dance, art house cinema. I also think the class could've benefitted from a few examples, i.e. watching a Nollywood film, reading a newspaper article, etc. 

Because the class was not composed of Africanists, the brief historical explainers before discussion were helpful in facilitating dialogue. I'd maybe go a step further and offer them before students do the readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like seminars on Zoom are very different from the one in-person, but it all worked out pretty well, because there were only 5 of us.
I thought Professor Keaney made the class as good as it could be given the format. He acknowledged how difficult this semester was and worked to make us feel comfortable.
The professor was wonderful, humane and accommodating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely! I took this class for writing credit and it was my best decision. Professor Keaney helps students a lot and it makes the learning environment very nice and low-pressure. Even if you do not have a background in history of Africa, take the course if the topic sounds appealing to you.
YES - Best and Kindest Professor! Really interesting content
Yes! Take whatever class you can with Professor Keaney.

I would absolutely recommend this course, if you want to learn more about the African region, how media was/is used to reach colonial aims, or the intersection of both. Professor Keaney is great, and I loved how many mediums we learned about throughout the course. This course was also a great writing credit (one 2-3 page paper, one 5-6 page paper, and one 7-8 page final paper), especially because Professor Keaney makes you submit rough drafts - in this way, you always receive copious and clear feedback, and feel like you are improving as a writer with each paper you submit.
Yes, provided they're interested in the subject matter!

extras.title:
HIST 369J 01
        Media and Power in Africa
